content: Dad's birthday is March 15th. He'll be turning 62 this year. We usually celebrate with a family dinner at his favorite steakhouse, Sullivan's, where he always orders the ribeye medium-rare with a loaded baked potato. Last year we surprised him with a cake shaped like a golf ball.

Dad loves playing golf more than almost anything else. He tries to play every Saturday morning with his buddies Tom, Jerry, and Mike at Pine Valley Golf Club. They've been playing together for over 20 years now, and they have a standing 7:30am tee time that Dad refuses to miss unless there's a genuine emergency.

Dad's been really frustrated with his golf game lately. He keeps slicing his drives and blaming it on his equipment. Last weekend he came home in a terrible mood after shooting 98, which is way above his usual. He spent the whole evening watching YouTube videos about golf swings.

I asked Dad directly what he wants for his birthday this year. He got this wistful look and said 'something to help my golf game would be nice.' Then he launched into a 20-minute explanation about how his current equipment is holding him back and how the technology has changed so much since he bought his clubs.

Dad keeps complaining that his golf clubs are completely outdated. Especially his driver - it's from 2016 and he says the sweet spot is tiny compared to modern drivers. Every time we watch golf on TV together, he points out the clubs the pros are using and sighs.

Dad came home from golf last week absolutely frustrated. He said his driver is warped and he can't hit a straight shot to save his life. He showed me how the face has this slight twist that he claims is causing all his slices. He even drew diagrams on a napkin to explain it.

We were watching the PGA tour together when a Callaway commercial came on. Dad literally sat up in his chair and said 'That's the Paradym driver - Jerry got one and added 20 yards to his drive.' He then spent the next hour researching it on his iPad and showing me comparison videos.

Dad's golf handicap has been stuck around 18 for years. His lifelong goal is to break 90 consistently, but he's been hovering in the low-to-mid 90s forever. He tracks every round in a little notebook and gets genuinely frustrated when he can't see improvement.

Mom let slip that she already bought Dad a new Seiko watch for his birthday. It's a nice automatic dive watch in silver. She's planning to give it to him at dinner, so I need to coordinate and not duplicate gifts. She's had it hidden in her closet for two months.

Dad's favorite color has always been navy blue. His closet is basically wall-to-wall navy blue polo shirts, most of them golf brands like Callaway and Titleist. Mom jokes that she could close her eyes when doing laundry and everything would still match.

Dad retired from Boeing last year after 35 years as a mechanical engineer. The transition was rough at first - he didn't know what to do with himself. But now he's settled into a routine of golf, woodworking in the garage, and watching way too much Golf Channel. He seems happier than he was working.

For Christmas we all chipped in and got Dad a really nice Titleist golf bag. It's all black with red accents and has his initials embroidered on it. He was genuinely touched and said it was the nicest bag he's ever owned. He shows it off to his golf buddies every chance he gets.

Dad absolutely hates surprise parties. When we threw him one for his 50th, he was visibly uncomfortable the whole time. Since then, we've stuck to small family dinners where he knows exactly who will be there. He likes to be able to mentally prepare for social situations.

Dad's current driver is an old TaylorMade R15 from about 8 years ago. He bought it on sale at a Dick's Sporting Goods closeout. The grip is worn smooth, the shaft has a small dent from hitting a cart path, and the face is noticeably scuffed. He knows he needs to replace it but keeps putting it off.

Dad and I played 18 holes together last month at Pine Valley. It was a beautiful day but he was frustrated the entire time. His drives kept slicing into the rough, and by the back nine he was just using his 3-wood off the tee. He blamed everything on his driver and wouldn't stop talking about needing new equipment.

Dad has a subscription to Golf Digest magazine that he's had since before I was born. He reads every issue cover to cover and always has the latest one sitting on the coffee table or in the bathroom. He dog-ears pages with equipment reviews and sometimes leaves them lying around as 'hints'.

Dad's regular golf group is Tom, Jerry, and Mike. They call themselves 'The Fairway Four' and have matching visors that Jerry's wife made them as a joke. Tom is the best player (12 handicap), Jerry just upgraded all his clubs, and Mike is the worst but the most fun. They've been playing together since their kids were in little league.

Last year for Dad's birthday I got him three boxes of Titleist Pro V1 golf balls. He was happy but mentioned he loses so many balls with his slice that he goes through them quickly. He said 'You know what would help me lose fewer balls? A driver I can actually hit straight.' Very subtle, Dad.

Dad told me his putter and irons are perfectly fine - he actually really likes them. But his woods, especially his driver and 3-wood, are ancient and desperately need replacing. He said if he could only replace one club, it would definitely be the driver since that's where he's losing the most strokes.

Dad watches the Golf Channel constantly, especially on weekends. He records tournaments and watches the highlights multiple times. It drives Mom absolutely crazy because she says the soft commentary puts her to sleep, but Dad finds it relaxing. Their TV is basically tuned to Golf Channel by default now.

Dad's home course is Pine Valley Golf Club. He's been a member for 22 years and his locker number is 247. He knows every groundskeeper by name, always tips the cart boys well, and has his picture on the 'Member of the Month' board from 2019 when he shot his best round ever (84).

Dad is surprisingly anti-gadget for a former engineer. He refuses to use a golf GPS watch even though I offered to buy him one. He says 'I've been eyeballing distances for 40 years' and insists the yardage markers on the course are sufficient. He also won't use a rangefinder.

Dad's lifelong dream is to play Pebble Beach Golf Links. It's been on his bucket list since he watched Tom Watson win the US Open there in 1982. He's looked into it multiple times but says the $600+ green fees are 'highway robbery.' Maybe for a big birthday we could make it happen.

Mom's birthday is June 22nd, and she's turning 59 this year. She's already told Dad she doesn't want anything golf-related as a gift (she made that mistake once and got a 'his and hers' putting green). She prefers practical gifts or experiences like spa days.

Mom has become obsessed with gardening since she retired from teaching. She spends hours every weekend in the backyard, has converted most of the lawn into flower beds, and subscribes to three different gardening magazines. Dad jokes that she's single-handedly keeping the local nursery in business.

Mom mentioned she needs new pruning shears because her current ones are completely rusted and don't cut cleanly anymore. She showed me how they leave jagged edges on stems, which she says is bad for the plants. She's been eyeing the Felco brand but thinks they're too expensive to buy for herself.

For Mom's last birthday I got her a beautiful Italian cookbook focused on Tuscan cuisine. She uses it constantly and has made almost every recipe at least once. Her favorite discovery was a simple lemon pasta that's now a weekly staple. She says it was the best gift I've ever given her.

When I asked Mom what she wants for her birthday, she said 'something practical, nothing frivolous.' She's very anti-clutter and hates getting gifts that just sit around. She'd rather have something she'll actually use every day than something decorative or sentimental that collects dust.

Mom's favorite flowers are tulips, especially the pink and white variegated ones. Every year Dad forgets and gets her roses instead because 'that's what you get women.' I've reminded him at least a dozen times but it never sticks. Mom just smiles and puts them in a vase anyway.

Mom has never liked golf and doesn't understand the appeal at all. She thinks it's boring, takes too long, and monopolizes too much of Dad's time. She's tried to learn twice over the years but gave up both times. Now she just accepts it as 'Dad's thing' and uses that time for her own hobbies.

I started a new job at a digital marketing agency called Bright Ideas Creative last month. The learning curve has been steep - I'm managing social media campaigns for three different restaurant chains. The hours are long but the team is great and I'm learning so much about analytics and content strategy.

My apartment lease is up at the end of August and I need to decide whether to renew or look for something new. The rent is going up $150/month which feels steep, but moving is such a hassle. My current place is close to work and I've finally gotten it set up the way I like it.

I've been trying to learn Spanish using Duolingo every morning before work. I'm on a 45-day streak now and can hold very basic conversations. My goal is to be conversational by the time Sarah's wedding happens in October since her fianc√©'s family is from Mexico and several relatives don't speak much English.

My best friend Sarah is getting married in October at a beautiful venue outside Denver. I'm going to be a bridesmaid, which means I need to book flights, find accommodations, and budget for the dress and bachelorette party. She's been my closest friend since college and I'm so happy for her.

I finally finished reading 'The Daily Stoic' after having it on my nightstand for six months. It's changed how I approach stressful situations at work. I've been trying to practice the idea of only worrying about things within my control. Dad would probably like it actually - might get him a copy.

My car needs new brakes badly - they've been squeaking for weeks and now they're grinding. The mechanic at Precision Auto quoted me $400 for front and rear brake pads plus rotors. It's more than I wanted to spend but probably not something I can put off much longer for safety reasons.

I signed up for a half marathon in May - the city's annual Spring Run event. It's 13.1 miles and I've never run more than 8 miles consecutively. I downloaded a training plan and need to start taking it seriously. My goal is just to finish without walking, nothing fancy about my time.

My sister Emma just announced she's pregnant! The baby is due in late September. Mom burst into tears and Dad just kept saying 'I'm going to be a grandpa' over and over. It's their first grandchild and you can tell they're already planning to spoil this kid rotten.

I've been completely hooked on this new sci-fi series on Netflix called 'Stellar Horizons.' It's about a generational spaceship traveling to a new planet. I've watched two seasons in a week which is embarrassing but I regret nothing. The plot twists are incredible.

My coworker Mike keeps raving about this Italian restaurant called Bella Notte downtown. He says their homemade pasta is life-changing and they have a great wine list. I keep meaning to go but it's a bit pricey for a solo dinner. Maybe I'll suggest it for a team lunch.

I finally paid off my student loans last month after eight years of payments! It's such a weight off my shoulders. I celebrated by just staring at the $0 balance for like ten minutes. Now I can actually start saving more seriously for a down payment on a condo someday.

The coffee maker in my kitchen finally died this morning - it just made a sad gurgling noise and stopped working. Had to stop at Starbucks which made me late for work. It was a cheap Mr. Coffee so not worth repairing. Need to research what to replace it with.

I've been seriously thinking about getting a cat. My apartment feels empty in the evenings and I could use the companionship. The shelter near my office has adoption events on weekends. I'm leaning toward an adult cat since they're calmer and harder to adopt out.

My gym membership at Fitness First expires next week. I've been going about twice a week which doesn't really justify the $50/month cost. Debating whether to renew or just buy some dumbbells and do home workouts. The accountability of the gym is nice but my schedule is so unpredictable.

Dad made his famous five-alarm chili last Sunday when I visited. It's a recipe he's been perfecting for 30 years - ground beef, three kinds of beans, and a secret blend of spices he won't share with anyone. He made a huge batch and sent me home with enough containers to last two weeks.

I have such fond memories of Dad coaching my little league team when I was 10. He took it so seriously, running actual practices and drawing up plays. We weren't very good but he made it fun. He still has the team photo in his office and brings it up whenever baseball season starts.

Dad is still driving the same silver 2011 Toyota Camry he bought when I was in high school. It has over 180,000 miles and some rust on the wheel wells. Mom keeps telling him to get something new but he says 'it runs fine, why would I waste money?' Classic Dad.

Dad has a bad knee from a skiing accident back in 1998. He tore his ACL and never got it properly fixed because he was stubborn about surgery. Now it acts up in cold weather and sometimes he uses a heating pad on it while watching TV. He refuses to see a specialist about it.

Dad's been talking about taking a trip to Scotland to play St Andrews, the 'home of golf.' He's been researching it obsessively and even started a separate savings account for it. His dream is to play the Old Course and walk the same fairways as all the legends.

Dad is a huge classic rock fan. His all-time favorite band is Led Zeppelin but he also loves Pink Floyd, The Who, and Jimi Hendrix. He has all their albums on vinyl and plays them on this old turntable in the basement. He's tried to get me into it but I just can't connect with it the way he does.

Every Fourth of July, Dad fires up the grill and makes his signature ribeye steaks. It's become a sacred family tradition - he starts marinating them the night before and guards the grill like it's his post. Even Uncle Bob isn't allowed to touch the tongs. The steaks are always perfect.

Dad has a severe shellfish allergy that we discovered the hard way at a family dinner when I was 12. He ate some shrimp and his throat started closing up. Now we're hypervigilant at restaurants about cross-contamination. He carries an EpiPen everywhere and we always check menus in advance.

Dad worked at Boeing for 35 years before retiring. He was a mechanical engineer specializing in landing gear systems for commercial aircraft. He's proud that parts he designed are still flying on 777s around the world. His Boeing coffee mug is still his favorite despite having dozens of others.

Mom and Dad are planning an Alaska cruise for their 35th wedding anniversary in August. They've been talking about it for years and finally pulled the trigger on booking. Mom wants to see glaciers, Dad wants to try fishing. They've never been on a cruise before so they're both nervous and excited.

I have a vivid memory of Dad teaching me to ride a bike in the driveway when I was 6. He ran alongside me for what felt like hours, holding the back of the seat. When he finally let go and I realized I was riding alone, I was so proud. He still tears up when he tells that story.

Dad has a reputation for falling asleep during movies, especially anything after 8pm. It doesn't matter how exciting it is - he'll start snoring within 30 minutes. Mom and I have a running joke about it. He always claims he was 'just resting his eyes' but the snoring gives him away.

The weather here has been absolutely miserable this week. Rain every single day, sometimes with wind that makes umbrellas useless. My commute has been twice as long because of accidents. I'm so ready for spring to arrive.

I really need to schedule a dentist appointment. It's been way too long since my last checkup and cleaning - probably over a year. I keep putting it off because I hate the dentist, but my parents have been nagging me about it and they're probably right.

My neighbor in 4B has a dog that barks constantly at night. I've started wearing earplugs to sleep but it's not enough. I've knocked on their door twice but they don't seem to care. Might have to talk to the building manager if it continues much longer.

Tried that new Thai restaurant on 5th Street that everyone's been raving about. Honestly, the pad thai was pretty mediocre - noodles were overcooked and the sauce was too sweet. The green curry was better but not worth the 45-minute wait. Won't be going back.

My iPhone battery has been draining incredibly fast lately - like 40% by lunchtime even with minimal use. It's a 3-year-old phone so probably time to either replace the battery or upgrade. Leaning toward just getting a new phone since the camera is outdated too.

I've been meaning to clean out my closet for months. There's stuff from college still in there that I'll never wear again. Mom's been on me about donating things I don't use. I keep putting it off because it feels overwhelming but I really need to just do it.

Mom makes the most incredible apple pie using Grandma's secret recipe that's been in the family for generations. She only makes it on special occasions and Thanksgiving. The crust is perfectly flaky and she adds just a hint of bourbon to the filling. I've tried to get the recipe but she says I'll have to wait until she's gone.

Mom's been taking pottery classes at the community center every Tuesday night. She's really gotten into it and made me this adorable but very lopsided coffee mug. It's bright blue and doesn't sit quite flat, but I use it every morning because it makes me smile thinking of her making it.

Mom worries about everything constantly. She calls it 'being prepared' but Dad and I call it 'catastrophizing.' If I don't answer my phone on the first ring, she assumes I'm dead in a ditch somewhere. It comes from a place of love but it can be exhausting. Dad says she's been this way their entire marriage.

Mom got a new puppy last month - a golden retriever named Biscuit. He's 4 months old and absolutely adorable but also completely insane. He chews everything and has so much energy. Dad pretends to be annoyed but I caught him baby-talking to Biscuit when he thought no one was watching.

The big family reunion is scheduled for the second weekend of August at Uncle Bob's lake house in Wisconsin. It'll be the first time the whole extended family has gathered since before COVID. Grandma's really excited - it might be over 50 people including all the cousins' kids.

My brother Kevin just got promoted to senior manager at his consulting firm. Mom won't stop bragging about it to anyone who will listen. Dad's proud too but shows it differently - he just keeps slapping Kevin on the back and saying 'that's my boy.' I'm genuinely happy for him even if the comparisons get old.

Grandma's 90th birthday is coming up in April and we're planning a big party at the church hall. The whole family is coming in from out of town. I'm on the decoration committee and we're doing a 'through the decades' theme with photos from each era of her life. She's sharp as a tack and probably our last grandparent.

For Christmas, Dad bought Mom a Peloton bike. We all thought it would become an expensive clothes hanger, but she's actually using it every single day. She's lost 15 pounds and is obsessed with the instructors. She even joined some online community of other Peloton users.

Had the strangest dream last night about flying over my hometown. Everything looked different but familiar at the same time. I woke up feeling really unsettled and couldn't shake it all day. My therapist says dreams like that usually mean I'm processing something unconsciously.

Really bummed that my favorite coffee shop, The Daily Grind, closed down permanently. They had the best cold brew in the city and the baristas actually knew my name and order. They couldn't survive the rent increase. Now I'm a coffee shop orphan trying different places each morning.

I keep telling myself I should start meditating. Everyone says it helps with stress and anxiety, and the Headspace app is just sitting on my phone unused. I've tried a few times but my mind just races. Maybe I need to give it more of a real try with lower expectations.

The stock market has been absolutely wild lately with all the tech volatility. I've stopped checking my 401k daily because it was giving me anxiety. Just going to trust the long-term strategy and stop obsessing over daily fluctuations. That's what Dad always advises anyway.

I bought a small pothos plant for my desk at work hoping to brighten up my cubicle. I've killed three plants in the past year so this is an experiment. My coworker says pothos are nearly impossible to kill, which feels like a challenge. I've set reminders to water it every Monday.

I remember Dad teaching me how to change a tire in the driveway when I was 16. He was so patient, making me do it three times until I could do it without help. He said it was an essential life skill that every driver should know. I've actually used that knowledge twice since then.

Dad's backyard shed is a disaster zone full of tools he never uses and projects he never finished. There's a half-built birdhouse from 2015 and exercise equipment from Y2K. Mom's been begging him to clean it out for years. He always says he'll 'get to it' but never does.

Dad has this impressive collection of vinyl records, mostly classic rock from the 70s. He has original pressings of albums by Led Zeppelin, Pink Floyd, and The Eagles that are probably worth decent money. He plays them on Sundays while reading the newspaper, which feels very nostalgic.

Dad has this weird quirk where he refuses to use the dishwasher. He insists on hand-washing every dish because he says the machine doesn't get things properly clean. Mom gave up fighting him on it years ago. He stands at the sink after every meal scrubbing everything while listening to talk radio.

Dad's been growing tomatoes in the backyard garden and he's gotten surprisingly good at it. He has six different varieties and spends hours tending to them. He brought me a bag of fresh ones last week and they were genuinely delicious - so much better than store-bought. He was beaming with pride.

Dad makes the absolute worst puns and jokes constantly. Like painfully bad jokes that make everyone groan. But he laughs at his own jokes so hard that it's actually endearing. It's become part of his identity - 'Oh that's just Dad being Dad.' Deep down we all secretly love it.

Dad's morning routine is militaristically consistent. He wakes at 5:45am, has coffee at exactly 6am while reading news on his iPad, eats the same breakfast (two eggs, wheat toast, orange juice), and is dressed by 7am. This has been his routine for decades and he gets genuinely thrown off if anything disrupts it.

Dad's golf buddy Jerry just got the new TaylorMade Qi10 driver and has been showing it off at the club. Dad tried it at the range and hit the best drives of his life. He came home talking about it nonstop, looking at prices online, and sighing dramatically every few minutes. Very subtle hints.

I remember Dad taking me to my first baseball game when I was 8. We sat in the nosebleeds but I thought it was magical. He bought me a foam finger and a hot dog that was probably overpriced. The Mariners lost but I didn't care. It's still one of my favorite childhood memories.

Dad used to help me with math homework every night in middle school. He has this patient way of explaining things that made even algebra make sense. He'd use golf analogies for everything - like slope being the angle of a putt. I actually credit him with my decent math skills today.

The neighbors across the street, the Hendersons, just put their house up for sale. They've been there since before I was born. Mrs. Henderson used to babysit me. Dad's worried about who will buy it and whether they'll keep up the property. He's very particular about the neighborhood aesthetics.

My therapist suggested I start journaling to process stress from work. I bought a nice leather notebook but have only written in it twice. Something about putting feelings on paper feels vulnerable. But she says consistency is key so I'm trying to commit to at least a few sentences daily.

I've been craving a vacation badly. Haven't had real time off since last summer. Thinking about a solo trip somewhere warm in April - maybe Puerto Rico or Costa Rica. Nothing fancy, just a beach and some time to read books without checking Slack every five minutes.

My college roommate Amanda is going through a divorce and I've been on the phone with her a lot lately being supportive. It's exhausting but she was there for me during my breakup so I want to return the favor. She's moving back to the city next month which will be nice.

Dad's old golf shoes finally fell apart. The soles literally separated from the uppers during his round last Saturday. He's been wearing them since 2008. He begrudgingly bought new ones but complained the whole time about how shoes 'don't make them like they used to.'

Mom hosted book club last week and made her famous spinach artichoke dip. She was so stressed about the house being perfect that she cleaned for three days straight. Dad and I had to hide in the basement to stay out of her way. The evening went great though.

I spent all of last Sunday reorganizing my kitchen cabinets. Found spices that expired in 2019 and three identical can openers. It's amazing how much stuff accumulates. The Marie Kondo method is no joke - I threw out two garbage bags worth of stuff that definitely didn't spark joy.

My work laptop has been running incredibly slow lately. IT says it's a 5-year-old machine and they won't replace it until it literally dies. I've resorted to restarting it twice a day just to keep it functional. The spinning wheel of death is my constant companion.

Dad called me last night just to chat, which he rarely does. We talked for an hour about nothing in particular - his golf game, my work, Mom's pottery, random childhood memories. It was really nice. I should call him more often instead of just texting.

The building next to my office is being demolished and the noise is unbearable. Jackhammers starting at 7am, dust everywhere, and my window vibrates constantly. They say it'll be six more months of construction. I've started wearing noise-canceling headphones all day.

I tried making Mom's pot roast recipe last weekend and it turned out terribly. Overcooked and dry despite following her instructions exactly. Called her and she laughed, saying 'every oven is different' and gave me adjustments to try next time. Cooking is harder than it looks.

Dad mentioned at dinner that his old golf partner Frank passed away last week. They hadn't played together in years but it clearly affected him. He got quiet and said 'we're all getting older.' Made me want to appreciate the time we have with him more.

My boss announced she's leaving the company for a competitor. She was the best manager I've ever had - supportive, fair, and actually good at her job. Now I'm nervous about who will replace her. The team morale has already dropped significantly since the announcement.

I finally got around to backing up all my photos to the cloud. Over 15,000 photos spanning a decade. Scrolling through them was an emotional rollercoaster - old pets, ex-relationships, trips with friends. Took hours but felt good to have them safely stored.

Dad's been complaining about back pain from sitting too much. Mom got him a standing desk converter for his home office but he refuses to use it. Says it 'looks ridiculous' and he 'can't think standing up.' It's still in the box in the corner of the room.

My high school reunion is coming up this summer - 15 years already. Part of me wants to skip it because I wasn't particularly close with anyone, but another part is curious to see how everyone turned out. Still have a few months to decide.

I've been trying to cook more and order delivery less. It's better for my wallet and health but requires so much planning. I now spend Sunday afternoons meal prepping which is boring but the weeknight convenience is worth it. Dad would be proud - he's always saying I eat too much takeout.

The elevator in my building broke down again yesterday - third time this month. I live on the 8th floor and climbing those stairs after a long day is brutal. The building management keeps promising repairs but nothing changes. Might actually factor into my lease renewal decision.

Dad sent me a link to a YouTube video about the 'best drivers of 2024' with no message, just the link. Classic passive-aggressive hinting. The Callaway Paradym Ai Smoke was number one on the list. I took a screenshot as evidence of what he wants for his birthday.
